I walked through the desolate landscape, kicking up dust with every step. The world had ended 20 years ago, and I’d been alone ever since. At first, it was survival, scavenging for food and shelter. But as time passed, I realized there was no one left. Not a single person, animal, or insect. Just me, alone in this vast, empty space.
To fill the void, I started leaving voicemails for myself. Short messages, simple greetings, or fragments of memories. It became my only comfort, the sound of human voices in a world devoid of life. Every day, I’d call my voicemail, listening to the same voices from the past. “Hi, this is Cindy.” “Hi you reached Bob.” “You know what to do at the beep.”
Years turned into decades, and the calls continued. I couldn’t bring myself to stop, even though there was no response. It was like talking to ghosts, but I needed to hear those voices. They kept me sane, gave me hope, and reminded me that I wasn’t completely alone.
But one day, something changed. The beep sounded different, louder, and more urgent. My heart skipped a beat as I picked up the receiver, bracing myself for another lonely message. Instead, a voice greeted me, clear and strong.
“Hello…hello? Oh my God, hello!”
I stumbled backward, my eyes wide with shock. My hand clutched the receiver, my fingers trembling. For the first time in 20 years, I wasn’t alone. Someone was on the other end of the line.
I tried to speak, to ask questions, to make sense of this miracle. But my voice caught in my throat, reduced to a stammer. All I could manage was a weak “Hello?”
The voice on the other end hesitated, then replied, “Hi, is anyone there? I’ve been trying to reach you for so long.”
My mind raced, trying to process this incredible turn of events. Alive! Someone was alive out there! I let out a shaky laugh, barely audible above the static on the line. “Y-yes,” I managed to stutter. “There’s someone on the line. I’ve been calling for 20 years.”
“Twenty years?” The voice repeated, incredulous. “How did you survive?”
I shook my head, still trying to wrap my mind around this revelation. “I don’t know,” I admitted, my voice barely above a whisper. “I just kept calling, hoping someone would answer.”
There was a pause on the other end of the line, filled with unspoken questions. How could someone survive 20 years without finding another living soul? What drove you to keep calling? Why didn’t you give up?
I didn’t have answers, but I knew I couldn’t hang up now. This was the first sign of life I’d heard in two decades, and I wouldn’t let it go. So I spoke, pouring out my fears, hopes, and dreams into the receiver. And when I finally hung up, I knew my life would never be the same again.

And yet, even as I marveled at the sheer scale of it all, I couldn't shake off the feeling of isolation that had crept up on me over the past few weeks.
It started innocently enough – a way to pass the time during the long stretches of solitude. I had created an imaginary friend, a constant companion who I could talk to whenever I needed someone to share my thoughts with. It was just a game, a way to keep myself sane in the face of an infinite blackness that seemed to stretch out in every direction. But as the days blended together, my imaginary friend grew more real to me, until it became hard to tell where reality ended and fantasy began.
I knew I shouldn't be surprised when, upon finally returning to Earth after months in space, Mission Control stopped me. There was something unexpected waiting for me on my ship – an unidentified lifeform, one that didn't quite fit the usual patterns of bacteria or other microorganisms found in deep space. It was like nothing anyone had ever seen before, and it had somehow managed to elude detection for so long.
I felt a shiver run down my spine as I boarded the ship again, my mind racing with possibilities. Was this some kind of alien life? Could there really be something living out there in the void, something that had been hiding from us all these years? My imagination ran wild with images of distant worlds teeming with life, of civilizations far older and wiser than ours.
But as I entered the ship, I realized that wasn't what awaited me at all. The lifeform wasn't anything like any organism I had ever seen before – it was my imaginary friend. It had taken shape on my ship, growing and evolving right before my eyes, until it was almost indistinguishable from the real thing. And yet, despite its physical presence, there was something unsettlingly ethereal about it, a feeling that it might vanish at any moment.
"What do we do now?" I asked myself aloud, as Mission Control broke the silence. "How did this happen? How did my imaginary friend become real?"
I didn't have answers then, and I still don't now. All I know is that my life will never be the same again, that my perception of reality has shifted forever. Because out there in the darkness, something is waiting for us, something that we can't quite explain or understand. And it may be closer than we think.
